title: What is this LP system...
body:
How does Rito expect people and encourage people to play and grind ranked if a winning game earns 13ish LP and a loss takes 22 points.
Even after a win streak of 4 or 5 +, you could lose it all after losing all if not more points from 2 losses.

replies.body:
> [{quoted}](name=Ediwir,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=gyvjtUnM,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-05-26T00:46:29.688+0000)
>
> So, there's a value called MMR, which represents your level of skill.
> 
> MMR determines the level of your teammates (approx) and the average MMR of your team determines the average MMR of your opponents.
> While you play your game, the system compares the relative MMR scores and runs probabilities of the outcome - let's say it's betting on the winner.
> Your odds of winning determine how much your MMR will change at the end of the game: good odds will translate into a relatively small gain, or a pretty big loss if you lose, while bad odds will mean you won't lose much, or you'll win a lot if you succeed.
> 
> This, in short, is the MMR system, which is an adaptation of the Elo system (originally used for chess, but later moved to professional basketball, soccer, baseball, and a few thousand other sports and games with a ladder system).
> 
> Now with the hard part.
> 
> The MMR value is hidden. What you CAN see is the tier system.
> Each tier/division has a corresponding "ideal MMR" value. By comparing your Current MMR with the Ideal MMR of your division, the system calculates a discrepancy, and moves you up or down the ladder according to that discrepancy, using the LP values.
> If your Current MMR (after the game) is higher than the Ideal MMR of your division, you'll have a large gain or a small loss, and move up.
> If your Current MMR (after the game) is lower than the Ideal MMR of your division, you'll have a small gain or a large loss, and move down.
> Once you reach a sufficient total of LP, you go into a Promotion series. You know the rest.
> 
> This means that while you have an accurate and very mobile rating, you also have a relatively slow, smooth variation in divisions. This was made for two reasons: first, it gives a more immediate idea of rating and growth, as it gives you a sense of progression, or "climb". Second, it prevents abrupt changes, such as dropping 300 points in MMR due to a losing streak (your MMR will still drop, but it'll take longer to lose divisions and you might be able to reduce the drop with a few victories after).
> Some note that the pure, plain MMR gives a more immediate information and is more reliable, BUT it's apparently harder to understand. I am personally one of those...
> 
> ps.
> Placements:
> You start with a MMR of 1200, which is roughly equivalent to Silver IV.
> After placement matches, where MMR gain/loss is increased for higher variance, you are placed in the tier and division closest to your current rating.
